case_name: Ahmedabad Millowners Association v. Textile Labour Association

facts.text: Appeals are Civil Appeals Nos. 167 to 173, 537 and 538 of 1965 by special leave from award dated October 26, 1964 of Industrial Court Gujarat in Reference I.C. No. 67 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 167 to, 173, 537 and 538 of 1965. Appeals by special leave from the award dated October 26, 1964 of the Industrial Court Gujarat in Reference  I.C.  No. 67 of 1964.

facts.text: Industrial dispute between appellants (Ahmedabad Millowners Association and 67 employers) and respondent (Textile Labour Association).

anchor.surface_text: This is a group of seven appeals which arise from an industrial dispute between the appellants, the Ahmedabad Millowners Association, Ahmedabad, and 67 em- ployers on the one hand, and the respondent, the Textile Labour Association, Ahmedabad, on the other.

facts.text: Dispute referred by Government of Gujarat to Industrial Court under section 73 of Bombay Industrial Relations Act, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: This dispute was referred by the Government of Gujarat to the Industrial Court, Gujarat, under section 73 of the Bombay Industrial Relations Act, 1946  No. XI of 1947   hereinafter called the Act .

facts.text: Dispute consists of three questions regarding payment of dearness allowance based on Consumer Price Index for Ahmedabad.

anchor.surface_text: The dispute itself companysisted of three questions. These questions have been thus stated in the reference  1  Whether under the award of the Industrial Court, Bombay, dated the 2nd March, 1950, in Reference  1C  No. 189 of 1949  as subsequently modified  read with award of the Industrial Court dated the 27th April, 1948, in Revision Petition No. Misc. 1 of 1947, the Ahmedabad Millowners Association and the emploers mentioned in the Annexure are bound to payness allowance to their employees on the Consumer Price Index Numbers for working class for Ahmedabad published by the State Government since February, 1964, by using the index numbers in the series for Ahmedabad companypiled by the Labour Bureau, Simla, and the linking factor of 3.17 adopted for linking that series to the State series with the old base If number, whether the said Ahmedabad Mill- owners Association and the employers mentioned in the Anexure should pay dearness allowance to their employees for March, 1964 and subsequent months in terms of the aforesaid awards, by treating the index numbers for working class for Ahmedabad published by the State Government since February, 1964, as the index numbers in the State series companypiled on the basis of the family budget survey made in 1926-27 If number, how the dearness allowance to the aforesaid employees for March 1964 and onwards should be paid on the index numbers for Ahmedabad published by the State Government since February, 1964.

facts.text: Industrial Court answered first question in favour of appellants, second and third in favour of respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Court has answered the first question in favour of the appellants, whereas the two remaining questions have been answered in favour of the respondent.

facts.text: Industrial Court directed payment of dearness allowance using index numbers from Labour Bureau Simla series with linking factor 3.17 at rate of 2.84 pies per day for rise over pre-war figure 73.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appellants have been directed to pay dearness allowance to their employees for the month of March, 1964 and for subsequent months on the companysumer price index numbers for working class for Ahmedabad published by the State Government since February, 1964,  by using the index numbers in the series for Ahmedabad companypiled by the Labour Bureau, Simla, and the linking factor of 3.17 adopted for linking that series to the State series with the old base  at the rate of 2.84 pies per day for rise of each point in the companyt of living index number over the pre-war figure 73.

facts.text: 75% of average dearness allowance of first six months of 1959 (Rs. 63-15-9 per month) consolidated with basic wage.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Court has further directed that as per the award in Miscellaneous Application  1C-G  No. 1 of 1960, 75 of the average dearness allowance of the first six months of 1959, i.e., Rs. 63-15-9 per month of 26 working days, shall be companysolidated with the basic wage

facts.text: Directions effective from January 1, 1965, arrears by April 30, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Court has made it clear that these directions should be given effect to from 1st of January, 1965 and the difference between what is paid and what has become payable under the present award shall be paid on or before April 30, 1965.

facts.text: Agreement between Fine Knitting Co. Ltd. and Textile Labour Association; award applies only to spinning department.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that before the Industrial Court an agreement had been reached between the Fine Knitting Co. Ltd. of Ahmedabad and the Textile Labour Association, and the award has, therefore, provided that the directions issued by it shall apply only to the spinning department of the Fine Knitting Co. and number to the hosiery department.

facts.text: Special leave granted on January 5, 1965; appeals listed for hearing week commencing March 8, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: On January 5, 1965, while granting special leave to the appellants, this Court directed that the statements of the case should be dispensed with and the appeals be listed for hearing in the week companymencing March 8, 1965.

facts.text: Second World War broke out in September 1939, cost of living rose, Textile Labour Association demanded dearness allowance.

anchor.surface_text: The story about the payment of dearness allowance to textile industrial employees at Ahmedabad takes us back to the time when the Second World War broke out in September, 1939. As is well-known, as a result of the said War, the companyt of living shot up and in companysequence, the industrial employees at Ahmedabad who had organised themselves as the Textile Labour Association, Ahmedabad, raised a demand for payment of dearness allowance.

facts.text: Industrial Court award in Case No. 1 of 1940 based on 1926-27 budget inquiry, datum index 73 for August 1939.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Court examined the matter at great length and came to the companyclusion that for the purpose of determining the quantum of dearness allowance to be paid to the employees, it would be reasonable to rely on the working class budget inquiry which had been companyducted by the Government of Bombay between August, 1926 and July, 1927. ... On the basis of the companyt of living index taken as 100 for the base year 1926-27, the index for August 1939 which stood at 73 was accepted as datum index

facts.text: Agreement on August 12, 1941 raised dearness allowance by 45% from July 1941, award September 15, 1941, neutralisation 96%.

anchor.surface_text: On August 12, 1941, an agreement was entered into between the. appellants and the respondent by which it was resolved that the dearness allowance to be paid to the employees in the member Mills of the appellant Association be raised by 45 per cent from the month of July, 1941, and in accordance with this agreement, an award was made by the Industrial Court on September 15, 1941. As a result of this award, neutralisation came to be effected to the extent of 96

facts.text: Member mills stopped dearness allowance from May 8, 1945 post-war.

anchor.surface_text: the member mills stopped the payment of dearness allowance with effect from May 8, 1945.

facts.text: Government of Gujarat stopped publishing old 1926-27 series cost of living index from February 1964.

anchor.surface_text: published by the State Government since February, 1964,

facts.text: New series published by Labour Bureau Simla with base 1960=100, linking factor initially 2.98, later adjusted.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of India began to publish companysumer price index number for the city of Ahmedabad, having index number 100 for the base year 1960. ... The Government of India companysidered this problem and indicated that 2.98 would be a proper linking factor.

facts.text: Expert Committee under Dr. M.B. Desai recommended linking factor 3.17.

anchor.surface_text: The other recommendation which it made was that the companyversion or the linking factor should be 3.17 as against 2.98 per point in the new series.

facts.text: Government of Gujarat accepted linking factor 3.17 on February 29, 1964, discontinued old series from January 1964.

anchor.surface_text: On February 29, 1964, the Government of Gujrat issued another Press Note by which it accepted the second recommendation made by the Expert Committed to take the linking factor at 317 instead of 298. ... discontinued publication of the companyt of living index number of its 1926-27 numbers from January, 1964.

facts.text: Appellant Association resolved on March 30, 1964 to pay DA based on last published index December 1963.

anchor.surface_text: A general meeting of the members of the appellant Association was held on March 30, 1964, and it passed a resolution to the effect that the discontinuance of the publication of the companyt of living index by the Government of Gujarat made it impossible for the appellant Association to companyply with the terms of the existing award

facts.text: Respondent Secretary requested payment per converted index on April 3, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: by his letter addressed to the appellant Association on April 3, 1964, he requested the members of the appellant Association to pay dearness allowance to their employees according to the companyverted number published by the Government of Gujarat.

facts.text: Family living survey by Labour Bureau at Ahmedabad 1958-59, sample 722 families.

anchor.surface_text: The new series is based on the enquiry into 722 working class families companyducted in 1958-59 when the total population of the city was about 11 lakhs.

facts.text: Industrial Court rejected appellants' preliminary objection on validity of reference under s.73 without s.42 notice.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Court has rejected the appellants companytention and has held that the reference is valid.

issues.text: Whether the reference under section 73 of the Bombay Industrial Relations Act, 1946 is invalid because the requirements of section 42 of the Act had not been complied with before making the reference.

anchor.surface_text: the competence of the present reference. They contended that the reference under s. 73 of the Act was invalid, because, before making the reference, the requirements of s. 42 of the Act had not been complied with.

issues.text: Whether under the award of the Industrial Court dated 2nd March 1950 read with award dated 27th April 1948 the employers are bound to pay dearness allowance using the index numbers compiled by Labour Bureau Simla and linking factor of 3.17.

anchor.surface_text: 1 Whether under the award of the Industrial Court, Bombay, dated the 2nd March, 1950, in Reference 1C No. 189 of 1949 as subsequently modified read with award of the Industrial Court dated the 27th April, 1948, in Revision Petition No. Misc. 1 of 1947, the Ahmedabad Millowners Association and the employers mentioned in the Annexure are bound to pay dearness allowance

issues.text: If not, whether the employers should pay dearness allowance by treating the index numbers published by the State Government since February 1964 as the index numbers in the State series compiled on the basis of the family budget survey made in 1926-27.

anchor.surface_text: If not, whether the said Ahmedabad Millowners Association and the employers mentioned in the Anexure should pay dearness allowance to their employees for March, 1964 and subsequent months in terms of the aforesaid awards, by treating the index numbers for working class for Ahmedabad published by the State Government since February, 1964, as the index numbers in the State series compiled

issues.text: If not, how the dearness allowance to the employees for March 1964 and onwards should be paid on the index numbers for Ahmedabad published by the State Government since February 1964.

anchor.surface_text: If not, how the dearness allowance to the aforesaid employees for March 1964 and onwards should be paid on the index numbers for Ahmedabad published by the State Government since February, 1964.

issues.answer: using index numbers compiled by Labour Bureau Simla with linking factor 3.17

issues.text: Whether the provisions of section 42 control or govern the power of the State Government to make a reference under section 73.

anchor.surface_text: The question is is this assumption well-founded ? Let us then read S. 73 it reads thus - Notwithstanding anything contained in this Act, the State Government may, at any time, refer an industrial dispute to the arbitration of the Industrial Court,

issues.text: Whether there can be an industrial dispute without a notice of change having been given under section 42.

anchor.surface_text: It is, however, urged that the power conferred on the State Government by s. 73 is the power to refer an industrial dispute to the arbitration of the Industrial Court, and there can be no industrial dispute unless a notice of change has been given

issues.text: Whether the textile industry of Ahmedabad's financial position has substantially deteriorated warranting revision of wage structure including dearness allowance.

anchor.surface_text: the Industrial Court has found that, in its opinion, the textile industry of Ahmedabad is in a sound financial position.

arguments.claim: Industrial dispute can exist without s.42 notice per wide s.3(17) definition.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 17  of the Act defines an industrial dispute as meaning any dispute or difference between an employer and employee or between employers and employees or between employees and employees and which is companynected with any industrial matter.

arguments.claim: New family living survey by Labour Bureau 1958-59 unreliable due to inadequate sample size (722 families vs 11 lakhs pop).

anchor.surface_text: The new series is based on the enquiry into 722 working class families companyducted in 1958-59 when the total population of the city was about 11 lakhs.

arguments.court_reasoning: Sample size adequate per modern sampling techniques; permissible 2% error margin; quality over quantity.

arguments.claim: Interview method in new survey unscientific and unsatisfactory.

anchor.surface_text: the first companytention which was urged before the Industrial Court was that the family living survey which was companyducted by the Labour Bureau, Simla, in 1958-59, was unreliable, because the sample survey on which it was based was inadequate, and the interview method which was adopted

arguments.court_reasoning: Interview method feasible and standard; followed ILO/UN guidelines; progress since 1926.

arguments.claim: Linking factor 3.17 unscientific; should use new scheme with consolidated basic wage as base (1960=100).

anchor.surface_text: the scientific and rational way to deal with the problem presented by the new  1  53 B.L.R. 902 companysumer price index recently adopted by the Government of Gujarat would be to devise a scheme of dearness allowance afresh, taking the present basic salary as a base

arguments.court_reasoning: Beyond terms of reference; would disturb industrial peace; arithmetic linking most suitable.

arguments.claim: Watch price behavior 2-3 years before linking factor.

anchor.surface_text: it would be more rational and scientific to watch the behaviour of prices for two or three years and then devise a linking factor on the average rise in prices during the said period.

arguments.court_reasoning: Not seriously pressed; arithmetic method with 3.17 accepted by experts.

arguments.claim: Textile industry paying capacity insufficient for new DA burden.

anchor.surface_text: the Industrial Court has found that, in its opinion, the textile industry of Ahmedabad is in a sound financial position.

arguments.court_reasoning: No substantial deterioration; sound financial position; basic principles not to be abandoned.

arguments.claim: New survey reliable; sample adequate, interview method proper.

anchor.surface_text: It urged that the, sample survey was companyducted on rational and scientific lines and it did number suffer from any infirmity at all.

arguments.court_reasoning: Technical advisory committee; ILO standards; 2% error margin sufficient.

arguments.claim: Linking factor 3.17 scientific; appellants' alternatives unreasonable.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent seriously challenged the appellants case that the operation of the linking factor was either unscientific, unreasonable or unjust

arguments.court_reasoning: Accepted by Govt of India, Expert Cttee; arithmetic method suitable.

arguments.claim: Industry financially sound; capacity argument untenable.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent emphatically companytended before the Industrial Court that the appellants financial position was perfectly sound and the argument that the burden would be beyond their capacity is wholly untenable.

arguments.court_reasoning: No substantial deterioration warranting revision downward.

holdings.text: The reference under s. 73 of the Act is valid even though the requirements of s. 42 have not been complied with.

anchor.surface_text: On a fair reading of s. 73, it is plain that it deals with the powers of the State Government to make a reference and as such, it is difficult to assume that the said powers of the State Government are intended to be controlled by the provisions of S. 42.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 73 contains 'notwithstanding anything contained in this Act' clause which overrides other provisions like s.42; s.42 prescribes procedure for parties, not for government references.

holdings.text: The power of the State Government under s.73 to refer industrial disputes is not controlled or governed by s.42.

anchor.surface_text: On a fair reading of s. 73, it is plain that it deals with the powers of the State Government to make a reference and as such, it is difficult to assume that the said powers of the State Government are intended to be controlled by the provisions of S. 42.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of s.42 and Ch.VIII applies to party-initiated changes, not government references under s.73; non-obstante clause repels control by s.42.

holdings.text: An industrial dispute can exist without a notice of change under s.42, as per wide definition in s.3(17).

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 17  of the Act defines an industrial dispute as meaning any dispute or difference between an employer and employee or between employers and employees or between employees and employees and which is connected with any industrial matter.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.3(17) defines industrial dispute broadly as any dispute connected with industrial matter, without requiring s.42 notice; subsisting award does not prevent disputes arising.

holdings.text: The preliminary objection to the competence of the reference is misconceived; Industrial Court correctly held reference valid.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, satisfied that the Industrial Court was right in coming to the conclusion that the preliminary objection raised by the appellants against the competence of the present reference was misconceived.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Terms of s.73 plain and unambiguous; power not controlled by s.42; justified on principle for urgent cases to prevent disorder or hardship.

holdings.text: The new consumer price index series compiled by Labour Bureau, Simla, based on 1958-59 survey is reliable; sample size of 722 families is adequate.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Sample size determined scientifically considering 2% error margin, modern sampling techniques; quality over quantity; progress since 1926-27 inquiry.

holdings.text: We see no reason to differ from the Industrial Court's view that the sample size does not introduce infirmity in the survey.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Permissible 2% error; scientific methods per ILO/UN standards; smaller samples achieve precision in modern statistics.

holdings.text: The appellants' contention that the sample size is inadequate is rejected; answer against appellants.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the answer to this question must be against the appellants.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Finite population correction shows precision depends on sample size n, not proportion; expert opinions support adequacy.

holdings.text: The textile industry of Ahmedabad is in a sound financial position with no substantial deterioration warranting revision of wage structure.

anchor.surface_text: the Industrial Court has found that, in its opinion, the textile industry of Ahmedabad is in a sound financial position.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirming Industrial Court's finding; no evidence of persistent substantial deterioration to justify abandoning basic wage principles.

In the result, the appellants have been directed to pay dearness allowance to their employees for the month of March, 1964 and for subsequent months on the consumer price index numbers for working class for Ahmedabad published by the State Government since February, 1964, by using the index numbers in the series for Ahmedabad compiled by the Labour Bureau, Simla, and the linking factor of 3.17 adopted for linking that series to the State series with the old base  at the rate of 2.84 pies per day for rise of each point in the cost of living index number over the pre-war figure 73.

outcome.relief_summary: Appellants directed to pay dearness allowance using new consumer price index with linking factor 3.17 at rate of 2.84 pies per day per point rise over pre-war index 73; 75% of average dearness allowance of first six months of 1959 consolidated with basic wage; effective from 1st January 1965 with arrears by April 30, 1965.

Schedule II Entry 9 Bombay Industrial Relations Act 1946 covers dearness allowance as part of wages, addressing the issue of whether employers are bound to pay dearness allowance using specific index numbers under the awards.

Schedule II Entry 9 Bombay Industrial Relations Act 1946 covers dearness allowance as part of wages, addressing whether employers should pay dearness allowance treating State Government index numbers since February 1964.

Schedule II Entry 9 Bombay Industrial Relations Act 1946 covers dearness allowance as part of wages, addressing how dearness allowance should be paid on Ahmedabad index numbers published by State Government since February 1964.

anchor.surface_text: On a fair reading of s. 73, it is plain that it deals with the powers of the State Government to make a reference and as such, it is difficult to assume that the said powers of the State Government are intended to be controlled by the provisions of S. 42.

The Industrial Court has answered the first question in favour of the appellants, whereas the two remaining questions have been answered in favour of the respondent. In the result, the appellants have been directed to pay dearness allowance to their employees for the month of March, 1964 and for subsequent months on the consumer price index numbers for working class for Ahmedabad published by the State Government since February, 1964, by using the index numbers in the series for Ahmedabad compiled by the Labour Bureau, Simla, and the linking factor of 3.17 adopted for linking that series to the State series with the old base  at the rate of 2.84 pies per day for rise of each point in the cost of living index number over the pre-war figure 73.
